titlestmt.author: Processed by: Meghan Lyon

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The papers of economist Robert Clower consist of professional correspondence, writings, teaching materials, subject files, and some personal and legal materials from Clower's career, which stretched from 1949 until 1999.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Robert W. Clower Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Robert W. Clower, noted American economist, were received as a gift from Robert W. Clower to the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library between 1992 and 2001, with an addition arriving in 2014.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Initially processed by Kirk White, completed June 25, 1999.
Additions processed at box level by Lisa Stark and Ruth E. Bryan, 2001.
Fully processed at Level 3 by Meghan Lyon, October 2014.

eventgrp.event: Born in Pullman, Washington (the day Francis Ysidro Edgeworth, the great economist, died), son of F. W. Clower (Professor of Economics at Washington State University) and Mary V. Clower
Graduated from Pullman High School, 52nd out of 54 on academic honors list
Joined army. Thirty-one months of army service
Married Frances Hepburn (of Aberdeen, Scotland) in Wiesbaden, Germany
Returned to the U.S. and entered Washington State Univ. at Pullman as a freshman in summer session, 1946
Father died

Graduated B.A. Economics with highest honors from Pullman. Elected Phi Beta Kappa, Phi Kappa Phi scholastic honors. Began teaching economics at Pullman in senior year following the death of his father
Completed MA in Economics at Pullman
Took up residence in Oxford as Rhodes Scholar. Researched under John R. Hicks. Earned Bachelor of Letter, Economics, Oxford University, 1952 (retitled Master of Letters, 1978)
Assistant Tutor, New College, Oxford
Assistant Professor of Economics, Washington State University
Publication of "Price Determination in a Stock-Flow Economy" (with D. W. Bushaw), Economometrica July 1954
Visiting Professor of Economics, University of Punjab, Lahore, West Pakistan
Publication of Introduction to Mathematical Economics with D. W. Bushaw
Chairman, Department of Economics, Northwestern University
Publication of "On the Invariance of the Demand for Cash and Other Assets" with M. L. Burstein, Review of Economic Studies, October, 1960
Director, Economic Survey of Liberia
Visitor to Faculty of Economics, Cambridge University, Michaelmas Term
Editorial Board, The American Economic Review
Publication of "The Keynesian Counter-Revolution: A Theoretical Appraisal," in The Theory of Interest Rates (Hahn and Brechling, eds.)
Visiting Professor of Economics, Makerere College, Kampala, Uganda
John Maynard Keynes Visiting Professor of Economics, University of Essex
Publication of Growth Without Development, an Economic Survey of Liberia
Publication of "A Reconsideration of the Microfoundations of Monetary Theory" ( Western Economic Journal)
Dean, School of Social Studies and Professor of Economics, University of Essex
Professor of Economics, UCLA
Visiting Professor, Monash University, Summer
Microeconomics, (an intermediate textbook) with J. F. Due
Visiting Professor, Bank of Italy Research Staff Seminar, Perugia, Italy
Managing Editor, Economic Inquiry
Visiting Professor, Institute for Advanced Study, Vienna, Austria
Visiting Professor, University of Western Ontario
Legally separated from first wife Frances (Hepburn) Clower
Adjunct Professor, Washington State University
Honorary Fellow, Brasenose College, Oxford
Married Georgene (?)
Managing Editor, The American Economic Review
Visiting Professor, University of Canterbury (Christchurch, N.Z.)
Visiting Professor, University of Siena
Benedict Distinguished Visiting Professor, Carleton College
Hugh C. Lane Professor of Economic Theory, University of South Carolina
Visiting Professor, University of Orleans (France)
Professor Emeritus, UCLA
Death of first wife Frances Hepburn Clower
Died, South Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Robert Clower Papers consist of professional correspondence, writings, teaching materials, subject files, and some personal and legal materials from Clower's career, which stretched from 1949 until 1999. Clower's correspondence includes many prominent names of 20th century economics: Milton Friedman, John R. Hicks, Peter Howitt, Arjo Klamer, David Laidler, Axel Leijonhufvud, Don Patinkin, Joan Robinson, Paul Samuelson, and others. Duke University faculty are represented in the Clower papers by Craufurd Goodwin, Neil DeMarchi, and Roy Weintraub. Also included are: Moses Abramowitz, Jess Benhabib, Clive Bull, David Colander, Paul Davidson, Frank Hahn, John Haltiwanger, Tom Hazlett, Roger Kormendi, Larry Kotlikoff, Robert Solow, and Sir Alan Walters. The Correspondence Series also includes a subseries of recommendation files. The collection also includes files of Clower's writings, ranging from notes and fragments to drafts and copies of published articles. Writings date from the 1950s through the 1990s. Topics covered in the collection include monetary theory, price theory, price determination, employment, banking, disequilibrium, stock-flow analysis, Keynesian economics/macroeconomics, Say's Law, and mathematical economics. The collection does not contain a complete set of drafts of Clower's writings. Many of the writings are untitled typescripts and fragments of notes.

The collection includes writings from Clower's father, F.W. (Fay Walter) Clower, also an economist; two copies of John Maynard Keynes's The General Theory of Employment Interest and Money, annotated by Clower; 5 cassette tapes with dictated letters; teaching materials from several economics classes taught by Clower throughout his career; and legal transcripts of 1979 court cases and hearings in which Clower testified.

The Robert Clower Papers consist of professional correspondence, writings, teaching materials, subject files, and some personal and legal materials from Clower's career, which stretched from 1949 until 1999. Clower's correspondence includes many prominent names of 20th century economics: Milton Friedman, John R. Hicks, Peter Howitt, Arjo Klamer, David Laidler, Axel Leijonhufvud, Don Patinkin, Joan Robinson, Paul Samuelson, and others. Duke University faculty are represented in the Clower papers by Craufurd Goodwin, Neil DeMarchi, and Roy Weintraub. Also included are: Moses Abramowitz, Jess Benhabib, Clive Bull, David Colander, Paul Davidson, Frank Hahn, John Haltiwanger, Tom Hazlett, Roger Kormendi, Larry Kotlikoff, Robert Solow, and Sir Alan Walters. The Correspondence Series also includes a subseries of recommendation files. The collection also includes files of Clower's writings, ranging from notes and fragments to drafts and copies of published articles. Writings date from the 1950s through the 1990s. Topics covered in the collection include monetary theory, price theory, price determination, employment, banking, disequilibrium, stock-flow analysis, Keynesian economics/macroeconomics, Say's Law, and mathematical economics. The collection does not contain a complete set of drafts of Clower's writings. Many of the writings are untitled typescripts and fragments of notes.

The collection includes writings from Clower's father, F.W. (Fay Walter) Clower, also an economist; two copies of John Maynard Keynes's The General Theory of Employment Interest and Money, annotated by Clower; 5 cassette tapes with dictated letters; teaching materials from several economics classes taught by Clower throughout his career; and legal transcripts of 1979 court cases and hearings in which Clower testified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clower's Writings Series includes everything from notes, fragments, drafts, and copies of published articles. The series includes Clower's book reviews, public lectures, book chapters, articles, and responses to other authors. Some of the titles include accompanying correspondence and edits by Clower and his collaborators. The materials are grouped alphabetically by title, with dates included when known. Miscellaneous untitled and loose excerpts are included at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clower's syllabi, coursepacks, exams, and lecture notes from his tenure at Northwestern, UCLA, and University of South Carolina are all represented in the Teaching Materials Series. Class titles or topics are included when known. Loose materials on various topics are filed later in the series, along with other special teaching engagements such as Clower's Fulbright at the University of Siena and his Perugia Lectures series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Professional Materials series includes an incomplete set of Clower's performance evaluations; agendas, notes, and fliers from Clower's attendance at various conferences; and various awards and achievements from Clower's career. Series also includes six audiocassettes. These have been itemized with available description below.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fliers, meeting agendas, conference programs, and other assorted materials from Clower's participation in various professional organizations as both an attendee and a presenter. Files are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assorted personal files, including biographical sketches and various versions and drafts of Clower's CV. This series also contains Clower family genealogy, clippings, and a pilot log. Miscellaneous writings, including an MA thesis, from F.W. Clower (Robert Clower's father) are also included in this series.

did.unittitle: F.W. Clower's MA thesis draft: Health Insurance Movement in the U.S.
F.W. Clower writings: The Passing of the Supernatural

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains Clower's collected research and subject files, arranged by topic or name. Authors represented include Clower's graduate students as well as other economists. The series includes Clower's annotated copies of Keynes's A General Theory, articles and essays by or about John Hicks, Milton Friedman, and David Laidler, and miscellaneous other research materials saved by Clower.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes 2 copies of The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money, with Clower's annotations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes file on Patinkin's article about Archibald and Lipsey, including correspondence and drafts.

did.unittitle: The Structure, Conduct, and Performance of the Cereal Industry, 1954-1964
University of South Carolina Dept. of Economics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence within the Robert Clower collection are divided into two subseries: General Correspondence and Recommendations. General Correspondence contains both personal and professional correspondence. Clower's personal correspondence consists mainly of postcards, Christmas cards, and birthday cards, though there are a few personal letters to and from longtime family friends. The professional correspondence is made up of correspondence between Clower and other economists and professors, usually discussing conferences and travel, networking, publications, reasearch, and writings. Prominent economists represented in this collection include Milton Friedman, Ingo Barens, Peter Howitt, Donald Patinkin, Kumaraswamy Velupillai (Vela), John Hicks, Axel Leijonhufvod, Charlotte Phelps, and Joan Robinson. The series also contains Clower's communications with publishers, journals, and various universities. The Recommendations subseries contains Clower's correspondence and drafts of recommendation letters for individuals applying to professional positions or graduate school. This subseries occasionally includes requests for reader reports or applications for research grants.

did.unittitle: CIES (Council for International Exchange of Scholars)

scopecontent.p: File of letters between Peter Howitt and Don Patinkin.
